questions.question: Question 1: Dialysis is not an absolute indication for patients who present with which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Dialysis is not indicated in patients who initially present with hyperkalemia. It is indicated in the 
case of refractory hyperkalemia that has failed to respond to other modalities of treatment. Indications for dialysis can be remembered using the mnemonic AEIOU: • Acidosis - metabolic acidosis that is refractory to medical treatment. • Electrolyte abnormality - refractory hyperkalemia and hypercalcemia. • Intoxication - barbiturates, alcohol, and lithium. • Overload - hypervolemia and pulmonary edema. • Uncontrolled hypertension (and) • Uremia - encephalopathy, pericarditis, asterixis, seizures, intractable nausea and vomiting, and 
bleeding diathesis.

questions.question:
Question 2: Which of the following is the most commonly used therapeutic modality for patients with 
end-stage renal disease?
questions.explanation:
The most common therapeutic modality for patients with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) is 
hemodialysis. The various modalities of renal replacement therapy include the following: • Dialysis: • Acute intermittent hemodialysis • Continuous renal replacement therapy - includes hemodialysis and ultrafiltration techniques • Peritoneal dialysis • CAPD - Continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis • CCPD - Continuous cycling peritoneal dialysis • NIPD - Nocturnal intermittent peritoneal dialysis • Renal transplant 738 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following is incorrect about hemodialysis?■

options.a: Dialyzers are made up of cellulose membranes
options.b: Bicarbonate is commonly used as a buffer
options.c: Glutaraldehyde is used as a reprocessing agent
options.d: Urea is cleared more efficiently than creatinine

questions.explanation:
In hemodialysis, the dialyzer is made up of biocompatible membranes derived from 
polysulfone. Cellulose is bio-incompatible and is no longer used. Hemodialysis is based on the principle of solute diffusion using an artificial semi-permeable 
membrane. Smaller molecules (urea) diffuse faster and are cleared more efficiently than larger 
molecules (creatinine). There are three components to this system: • Dialyzer - a chamber that contains compartments for blood and dialysate solution, separated by 
a semipermeable membrane. • Dialysate - a solution that helps in the removal of metabolic waste products. Bicarbonate is used 
as a buffer to correct acidosis in CKD patients. • Blood delivery system - consists of the vascular access and extracorporeal circuit. The dialyzers used during a session of dialysis are reprocessed and reused for the next dialysis 
sessions. The reprocessors used for dialyzers are: • Glutaraldehyde • Formaldehyde • Peracetic acid-hydrogen peroxide The following image depicts hemodialysis.

questions.question:
Question 4: A 50-year-old man with stage 5 chronic kidney disease is planned for hemodialysis. Which of 
the following is incorrect regarding the vascular access for this procedure?

options.a: Tunneled catheters are associated with lower infection rates
options.b: Access of choice is radiocephalic arteriovenous fistula
options.c: Most common complication of arteriovenous grafts is infection
options.d: Fistulas have higher long term patency rates

questions.explanation:
The most common complication of arteriovenous (AV) grafts is stenosis, not infections. 739 
Sold by @itachibot In order to perform hemodialysis, vascular or hemodialysis access must first be established. The 
preferred site is the forearm. The following types of vascular access may be used for hemodialysis: • AV fistulas: • Fistula refers to the anastomosis of an artery and an adequately large vein (either side-to-side or 
end-to-side). • This causes arterialization of the vein, thereby causing venous wall thickening and increasing 
venous diameter. • Fistulas need 4-6 weeks to mature before they can be used. • The access of choice is radiocephalic AV fistula (Brescia-Cimino fistula). • Fistulas have higher long-term patency rates than grafts. • Thrombosis is a common complication. The following image depicts a radiocephalic fistula. • AV grafts: • The artery and vein are connected by a prosthetic graft such as PTFE (polytetrafluoroethylene). • The advantage is that it can be performed with smaller veins. • Complications include stenosis (most common), due to intimal hyperplasia at anastomosis 
between graft and vein, and infections. • Central venous catheter: • Tunneled catheters are used for long-term IV access. As they tunnel through the skin before 
entering the vein, they have a lower risk of infection.

questions.question: Question 5: What is the rate of blood flow in the hemodialysis machine?
questions.explanation:
740 
Sold by @itachibot During hemodialysis, heparinized blood flows through the dialyzer at a rate of 250–450 mL/min. 
On the other hand, the dialysate flows in the opposite counter-current direction at 500–800 
mL/min.

questions.question:
Question 6: In a patient undergoing hemodialysis, which of the following can be used to monitor the 
adequacy of dialysis?
questions.explanation:
The adequacy of dialysis is determined by the urea reduction ratio. It is defined as the fractional 
reduction in blood urea nitrogen per hemodialysis session. It is calculated as (Co - C) / Co, where: Co - predialysis serum urea C - postdialysis serum urea The target urea reduction ratio is 65–70%.

questions.question:
Question 7: Which of the following has been most commonly implicated as a cause of dialysis-induced 
hypotension in patients?
questions.explanation:
Acetate is used as a buffer in the dialysate solution. It is the most common cause of 
dialysis-induced hypotension because of its vasodilatory and cardio-depressive effects. For this reason, acetate is less commonly used these days and has been largely replaced by 
bicarbonate.

questions.question: Question 8: What is the most common acute complication in patients who undergo hemodialysis?
questions.explanation:
Hypotension is the most common acute complication of hemodialysis, particularly among patients 
with diabetes mellitus.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 61-year-old man is brought to the casualty following a seizure episode. His wife says that he 
has been very drowsy and has not passed urine for the past 2 days. Investigations reveal 
serum urea of 71 mg/dl and creatinine of 5.6 mg/dl. He is referred for urgent hemodialysis. 
You would take all of the following precautions except:

options.b: Removing more fluid during the beginning than the end of the procedure
options.c: Maintaining fluid removal rate below 13 mL/kg/hour

questions.explanation:
Cooling, not warming, the dialysate before dialysis must be done to prevent hypotension during 
dialysis. Hypotension is the most common acute complication of hemodialysis. The mechanism is not fully 
understood and occurs due to multiple factors. However, the following precautions have been 
shown to frequently prevent this complication: • Careful calculation of the dry weight and adjustment of the filtration rate accordingly. • Ultrafiltration modeling such that more fluid is removed during the beginning than the end of 
the procedure. • Avoiding rapid fluid removal and maintaining the rate < 13 mL/kg/hour. • Avoiding heavy meals during dialysis. • Cooling of the dialysate during the dialysis. 741 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 10: A 67-year-old woman with CKD underwent her first session of hemodialysis. Towards the end 
of the session, she became drowsy and had a sudden seizure episode. What is the likely cause 
for this presentation?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of the dialysis disequilibrium syndrome or the reverse urea effect. 
It is an acute complication that occurs especially in patients undergoing dialysis for the first time. During dialysis, urea in blood vessels is rapidly removed as compared to that in the interstitium. 
This decreases the osmolality of blood. This results in a fluid shift from the blood vessels into the 
interstitium and brain parenchyma, causing cerebral edema. In order to prevent this, the rate of flow of dialysate must be adjusted to avoid the rapid removal 
of solutes.

questions.question:
Question 12: 733 
Sold by @itachibot A patient on hemodialysis may develop all of the following chronic complications except:
questions.explanation:
Hypovolemia is an acute complication of hemodialysis. The chronic complications of hemodialysis 
are: • Amyloidosis • Adynamic bone disease • Dementia (aluminum toxicity)

questions.question:
Question 13: A physician is evaluating a patient with carpal tunnel syndrome. He has been undergoing 
dialysis for the past 7 years. Deposition of which of the following is responsible for this 
condition?
questions.explanation:
742 
Sold by @itachibot Carpal tunnel syndrome in the setting of chronic dialysis is suggestive of dialysis-associated 
amyloidosis. It occurs due to the deposition of amyloid ß-2 in tissues. This condition is seen in patients undergoing long-term hemodialysis or continuous ambulatory 
peritoneal dialysis (CAPD). Amyloid deposition can lead to the following complications: • Destructive osteoarthropathies - carpal tunnel syndrome, flexor tenosynovitis • Subchondral bone cysts and pathologic fractures • Paraplegia - due to deposits along paravertebral ligaments and intervertebral discs • Visceral involvement - GI tract, heart, tongue Management involves providing symptomatic relief by means of analgesics, anti-inflammatory 
drugs, physical and occupational therapy, and surgical procedures. Renal transplantation is the 
treatment of choice.

questions.question:
Question 14: A 57-year-old man is referred urgently for management of pulmonary edema. He was 
diagnosed with stage-5 CKD 3 weeks ago but was reluctant to start dialysis. On examination, 
he is confused and has a flapping tremor. Investigations are as follows. Which of his clinical 
features will not improve with dialysis?
questions.explanation:
Renal osteodystrophy does not show improvement with dialysis. Failure of renal function leads to decreased renal vitamin D production. The resulting 
hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia, in turn, lead to secondary hyperparathyroidism. This can 
be corrected only by vitamin D and calcium supplementation. Other manifestations of renal dysfunction and uremia show improvement with regular dialysis 
sessions.

questions.question: Question 15: What is the most common cause of death in patients undergoing chronic dialysis?
questions.explanation:
Cardiovascular disease due to accelerated atherosclerosis is the major cause of death in patients 
with ESRD on chronic dialysis. Cardiovascular mortality is higher in dialysis patients compared to patients after transplantation.

questions.question:
Question 16: You are educating a patient about performing peritoneal dialysis at home. During this 
process, how much fluid is infused into the peritoneum?
questions.explanation:
In peritoneal dialysis, 1.5–3 L of dialysis fluid is infused into the peritoneal cavity. In this process, the peritoneum itself acts as a semipermeable membrane. A peritoneal catheter is 
used to infuse the fluid into the cavity. It is allowed to dwell for a set period of time usually 2–4 
hours to allow for the removal of metabolic waste products. The dialysis fluid contains osmotically 
active agents such as glucose or icodextrin. The following image shows the process of peritoneal dialysis. 743 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 17: A 56-year-old man presents with fever and severe abdominal pain for 2 days. He has been on 
peritoneal dialysis for the past 1 year. On examination, there is abdominal distension, 
guarding, and rebound tenderness. Which of the following is the most common cause of this 
condition?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario in a patient undergoing peritoneal dialysis is suggestive of peritonitis. It is 
most commonly caused by gram-positive cocci such as Staphylococcus, which spread from the 
skin.

questions.question:
Question 18: A woman is started on continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis. Which of the following 
complications is she unlikely to develop?
questions.explanation:
Weight gain is a complication of peritoneal dialysis, not weight loss. The complications of 
peritoneal dialysis include: • Peritonitis • Catheter-associated non-peritonitis infections • Weight gain • Metabolic disturbances - hypoproteinemia and hyperglycemia • Residual uremia - especially among patients with no residual kidney function • Insulin resistance • Hypertriglyceridemia

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following is incorrect about renal transplants?

options.a: ABO and HLA mismatch are relative contraindications
options.b: Contraindicated in overt AIDS and active hepatitis
options.c: Complications in donor include hypertension and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis
options.d: The most common cause of death after renal transplant is infections

questions.explanation:
The most common cause of death in renal transplant recipients is cardiovascular causes. It occurs 
in > 50% of patients. 744 
Sold by @itachibot Other complications in recipients include: • Infections • Most common - CMV. • Most specific - BK (polyoma) virus • Most common fungal - pneumocystis. • Malignancy - most commonly of skin and lip Donors can develop long-term complications related to premature failure of the single remaining 
kidney including: • Hypertension • Proteinuria • Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) ABO and HLA mismatch are relative, not absolute contraindications due to the availability of 
desensitization procedures. The absolute contraindications for transplantation are as follows: Recipient

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following is incorrect about rejection reactions following a kidney transplant?

options.a: Acute rejection can occur due to both type 4 and type 2 hypersensitivity reactions
options.b: Hyperacute rejection is a type 2 hypersensitivity reaction
options.c: Induction therapy for prophylaxis of rejection is cyclosporine, azathioprine, prednisolone.
options.d: Alemtuzumab is monoclonal antibody against CD52 used for immunosuppression

questions.explanation:
Cyclosporine, azathioprine, prednisolone constitute the prophylactic maintenance therapy used 
after renal transplant. Immunosuppressive therapy is given to reduce the risk of transplant rejection reactions. The 
following regimen is commonly followed: • Induction therapy: • Given at the time of transplant to reduce the risk of early acute rejection. • The preferred treatment is anti-lymphocyte serum and alemtuzumab. • Maintenance therapy: • Given to all kidney transplant patients except when the donor and recipient are identical twins. • The most common combination used is : 745 
Sold by @itachibot cyclosporine, azathioprine, and prednisolone (also known as triple therapy). • Belatacept is a co-stimulatory blocking antibody approved by the FDA for maintenance therapy. Rejection reactions can be hyperacute, acute, or chronic. Treatment of rejection is as follows: • First episode - IV prednisolone for 3 days • Failure to respond to prednisone or second episode - anti-thymocyte globulin

questions.question: Question 22: Which of the following lesions does not recur in the transplanted kidney?
questions.explanation:
Alport syndrome does not recur in the transplanted kidney. This is because it occurs due to an 
inherited defect in type 4 collagen in the glomerular basement membrane. This defect is absent in 
the transplanted kidney. Diabetic nephropathy, membranous glomerulonephritis, and lupus nephritis can recur in the 
transplanted kidney.

questions.question:
Question 23: Patients with which of the following conditions have the highest risk of disease recurrence 
after renal transplant? 736 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Patients with diabetic nephropathy have the highest risk of disease recurrence after renal 
transplant. Nearly 52% of transplant recipients have histological evidence of diabetic kidney 
disease/mesangial sclerosis at 10 years after transplantation. The recurrence rates of the other conditions are as follows: • Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis: 20-48% • Membranous glomerulonephritis: 10-45% • Lupus nephritis: 2-11% 746 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 24: What is the average life expectancy in patients following a living-donor kidney transplant?

options.a: Mutation of PKD-1 is responsible for 85% of cases
options.b: PKD-2 mutation has higher risk of end-stage renal disease than PKD-1
options.c: The PKD genes code for the polycystin protein
options.d: Cysts are formed only in 5% of the tubules of the kidney

questions.explanation:
The average life expectancy of a living-donor graft is around 14 years and that of a deceased-donor 
graft is around 10 years. 747 
Sold by @itachibot Cystic and Inherited Disorders of the Kidney
